Collections Fellow

The Collections Fellow will assist the Senior Curator in the research and preservation of the collection and will help perform care and arrangement of the collection, which includes natural history, technology, and art objects. Specifically, the Collections Fellow will research objects of unknown or incomplete provenance and assist in determining their disposition. The fellow will also expand his/her personal skills and knowledge by assisting in inventory and processing projects, research, cataloguing, exhibit de/installation, and packing and shipping artifacts.

Deadline for Internal Applicants: Monday, June 25,2018

MOS Employee/volunteer discount for July 4th event

Discounted MOS employee/volunteer tickets for Community Boating�s July 4th SAILabration

As you know the Museum of Science is no longer hosting the Let�s Celebrate July 4th event at the Museum.  One of the Museum�s donors heard this and offered to extend a discount to Community Boating�s fundraising event.  They are offering Museum of Science staff and volunteers a generous $75 discount to the Community Boating July 4 SAILabration Fundraiser for the Junior and Universal Access Program (Members have access to a $50 discount).  This discount applies to most of the seating options. 

Your tickets include a New England clam bake followed by Ben and Jerry�s ice cream, your choice of reserved or picnic table seating, DJ, photo booth, face painting, jumbotron video screens simulcasting the Boston Pops Fireworks Spectacular concert and fabulous river views right beside the Esplanade.

Register here for your discount (https://www.eventbrite.com/e/july-4-sailabration-fundraiser-for-the-junior-and-universal-access-program-tickets-35661377139?discount=MOS_STAFF).

If you have questions contact Community Boating directly at 617-523-1038.  

Please note, this link that provides access to the discount should not be shared as it is a special discount Community Boating is extending to MOS staff and volunteers for their fundraising event.  

We recommend taking public transportation if you are staying for the evening as the Museum Garage will close at 5pm.

Virtual Walk/Run/Bike

June 23 � 24 Last Call!

The Wellness Team has brought back this popular wellness event for a 2018 summer series! A virtual race is a race in which you can do on your own time, at your own pace, anywhere you would like. We will be building the race distance as the summer goes in hopes that it will keep you motivated to stay active this summer!

Participants will receive a personalized printable bib to wear while walking, running, or biking and a medal!

To participate in our virtual race all you have to do is:

  1. Sign up HERE by June 21, 2018
  2. Complete 1 mile the weekend of June 23 - 24
  3. Send proof of your distance to wellness@mos.org

How can you send us proof?

  • Screenshot your Heath App (iPhone)
  • Screenshot any other fitness tracking apps you may have (iPhone or otherwise)
  • Take a picture of your FitBit/Garmin/wearable device
  • Take a picture of your treadmill dashboard data

Send those screenshots and any pictures you take of your race to wellness@mos.org!

MOScar of the Month!

From the dozens of nominations we receive each week, the MOScars Team chooses a MOScar that we believe best exemplifies the spirit of the program across all categories each month.

�

Our May MOScar of the Month is�.Eric Workman

3 MOScars in one month, way to go Eric!

�

CONGRATULATIONS Eric Workman!

Best Service to Colleagues

Recognized by Patricia Sheppard on 05/09/2018

Subspace hosted the Somerville Cryptoparty for an after hours event. Their needs varied from network connectivity to user computing support. Eric went above and beyond not only deploying additional WAPs but staying through the event set up and kick off to make sure that everything ran smoothly and that both the activists and the attendees had what they needed. And all that after a long maintenance night the evening prior. Thank you Eric!

�

CONGRATULATIONS Eric Workman!

Best Service to Colleagues

Recognized by Joe Rivers on 05/10/2018

Eric noticed that part of the shelf on Skyline's lectern had broken away and would allow a laptop to slide off, possibly falling to the floor. He found the broken piece, glued and securely screwed it back in place. It's now stronger and sturdier than when brand new. Thank you Eric for taking the time and going beyond the call of duty (and job description) to fix that old piece of furniture that gets used almost every day.

�

CONGRATULATIONS Eric Workman!

Best Example of Museum Mission & Spirit

Recognized by Jake Babineau on 05/14/2018

Eric is the best example of a colleague who is always willing to help with something even if it isn't technically his job. He has been nothing but helpful to me since I started here. He recently repaired our podium without anyone asking and he helped a client for my department when I wasn't there to do it myself. He does all of this without expecting anything in return and without a complaint and I believe this is why he is the best example of the museum's mission and spirit!

�Thanks Eric!

Audio Visual Technician

The Audio Visual Technician performs set-up, operation, and break down of audio visual equipment throughout the building and grounds to support functions, special events, and meetings. Additionally, this position is responsible for working with internal or external stakeholders to ensure audio visual support needs are met in an organized, timely and professional manner. This position is full-time, 40 hours/week, with one weekend day and some holidays as required.

Dear all, 

On Thursday morning the Fundraising Events team will be hosting a Sunrise Yoga event to celebrate the Summer Solstice and International Day of Yoga from 6:00 a.m. to 8:00 a.m.! 

We will be using the back-half of the Lobby past the turnstiles for our yoga classes with preparation beginning as early as 5:00AM. Between the hours of 5:00AM-8:30AM, please utilize the Red Wing to access the Blue and Green wings (or Door 16 if coming up from the garage.) We wish to maintain a quiet, mindful library atmosphere for our event participants. A Public Safety officer will be posted in the lobby between these hours, and we will have signage beginning at the Concourse for all those parking in the garage. Following the classes, we have asked C&W to clean the floor in preparation for our 9:00am public opening.

Thank you in advance for your flexibility and patience. Our last yoga event in March was a huge success, bringing in a new audience to the Museum, and as an employee, it was fun to see something new in action take place in our lobby! If you have any questions, please feel free to reach out to me directly. 

Best wishes,
Gina Crotty, x4475

I'm sad to say it, but it's time to say thank you and good luck to Becky Smick as she heads on to her next adventure with the Cambridge Health Alliance.  Becky has worn many hats in the Museum since she first joined us as an intern for "Dinosaurs: Ancient Fossils, New Discoveries" in the summer of 2011.  In addition to her various roles in Interpretation, she was a Fellow with Live Presentations and an Ed Associate with the Hall of Human Life.  Becky's last day as Interpretation Coordinator will be Saturday, July 7th, but due to a variety of vacation plans, we'll celebrate her new directions the week before.  

Join us in Hornblower between 3:30 and 4:30 on Tuesday, June 26th to share stories, activities, and snacks!  

We'll head across the street to Lingos (new building) at 5.

Crystal is (almost) dead.  Long Live SSRS!

With profuse apologies that it has taken so long, Finance is pleased to announce the implementation of a new reporting system to replace Crystal, which, though still functional, has not had up-to-date data since we changed our main Accounting software back in November.

The new reporting tool is called Finance Reports in SSRS, and here�s the quick and dirty:
  • If you had access to Finance Reports in Crystal, you have access to Finance Reports in SSRS.
  • There�s a link to the system on the Accounting Hub page� (Under �On The Web�).
  • There�s a new �All About� on our Hub Page to help you use the system.
This project is still in its early stages.� Right now, only a couple of General Ledger reports are available.� We intend to slowly flesh out the system to reproduce all the reports you previously had in Crystal.� (In the meantime, Accounting can continue to provide those on an as-needed/upon-request basis.)

And Accounting will continue to send out those reports we e-mail to you each month. �This new system supplements the information you already get from us.

Many thanks to IT for getting this system up and running.
Staff Preview - Space: An Out-of-Gravity Experienc

Space: An Out-of-Gravity Experience
Staff/Volunteer Preview Event
Friday June 22, 2018; 3-6pm

Join us for a staff/volunteer preview of Space: An Out-of-Gravity Experience on Friday, June 22; 3:00 pm � 6:00 pm. Experience the sights, sounds, and even the smells on board the International Space Station in this interactive new temporary exhibit! This will be on exhibit starting June 24th, but why wait?

Please access this exhibit by entering the main Nichols entrance down the hallway from the second floor bathrooms across from Hall of Human Life. The door is across from the lobby balcony.

Friends and family are welcome to this event. Please note if you are planning to bring friends or family to this staff preview, please accompany them with your membership card.

Space was developed by the Science Museum of Minnesota and the California Science Center Foundation in cooperation with the Science Museum Exhibit Collaborative with major support from NASA.

If you have any questions about this event please contact Lorah Broderick at x0122.

Good morning,

This is just a gentle reminder that starting tonight at 6pm shortly after the box office closes IT will be performing our final storage migration of all Zeus shared folders and home directories.  If files and folders are not closed out, IT will close them to ensure that the data is properly migrated to the new device.  To avoid losing changes to files please close out of all files and folders promptly before 6pm.

We will send another email tonight when the migration window has completed.

As always, if you have any questions or issues, please contact our service desk, System Support Services, at ithelp@mos.org or call x0130.

Thank you,

Angela

All,

Please be advised that IIT will be performing a planned network maintenance on the following date and time:

Tuesday June 12th 2018 from 6:00pm to 11:59pm

As previously communicated, the Museum, and in particular EiE, received a donation from Dell EMC for a new storage device.  This has enabled the Museum to improve how we manage, store and backup much of our unstructured content.

In order to prepare for the final migration of data to the new device we ask that users close out of all shared museum file directories and personal work drives on the night of June 12th before 6pm so that IT can work with Dell EMC and maximize our final migration window. If files and folders are not closed out, IT will close them to ensure that the data is properly migrated to the new device.  To avoid losing changes to files please close out of all files and folders promptly before 6pm.

This maintenance is necessary to perform upgrades to our network and system infrastructure. We anticipate this scheduled outage will take approximately 4 to 6 hrs. to complete due to the storage migration of Zeus. During this maintenance window you may experience brief outages where servers, business applications, and or files may not be accessible both internally and externally. To ensure uptime and stability of our platform, we are performing this upgrade shortly after close of business so we can maximize our efforts to ensure business operations will not be impacted when we open the next day. 

If you have any questions or concerns please contact the Service Desk team at x0130. 

We thank you in advance for your attention and understanding.
Summer Youth Internship Program is almost here!

Hi everyone,

The Summer Youth Internship Program is right around the corner, starting with Summer Youth Orientation this Friday, June 15th. We look forward to hosting 35 Interns and 11 Program Assistants across 8 different departments in the Museum. Please say hello if you spot one of our great Youth this summer!

In addition to working in their home departments, interns will participate in 6 weeks of workshops, consisting of professional development on various topics and off-site STEM/Cultural field trips. These workshops will be held on Tuesdays, Wednesdays and Thursdays from July 10th through August 16th in the Gordon Wing classroom.

Want to get involved? We will be posting GSEs later this summer for field trip chaperones on the week of July 22nd and the week of August 19th. These will be a fun half-day opportunity to support our Youth as we explore local organizations together. 

Have additional questions? Feel free to send them to Christina Moscat at cmoscat@mos.org (x0329).

Best,

Christina

In preparation for the upcoming escalator work, Design Challenges has cleaned and sorted many of our materials. Free items are up for grabs in the central area of Lower Morse outside of the Lower Morse conference room. Materials are an eclectic mix including toys, science teaching/household supplies, craft materials and building materials. Everything not claimed will be thrown away on Tuesday evening.

Our own Jeannine Madrid was interviewed by Boston Magazine to talk about her cool job here at the Museum of Science! When asked what the best part of her job is, Jeannine said, "Besides making lightning, which is super fun, just sharing my passion for learning. I meet so many different kinds of people who all are here and we have this shared experience together, and they all walk away with a memory. That�s the best part for me."

You can read the full article here:

https://www.bostonmagazine.com/news/2018/06/08/lightning-museum-of-science-jeannine-madrid-i-love-my-job/

Good afternoon,

As previously communicated, the Museum, and in particular EiE, received a donation from Dell EMC for a new storage device.  This has enabled the Museum to improve how we manage, store and backup much of our unstructured content. 
 
What Does This Mean?
Information Technology will use the new device to replace our existing Zeus file server.  After a successful pilot over the past few months, we will finalize the migration of all Zeus shared folders and home directories on our regularly scheduled June Maintenance night on 6/12 starting at 6pm. 
 
What Can I Expect When This Takes Effect?
Do not panic! We will be retaining all file and folder permissions and will be retaining the existing �Zeus� naming convention in order to maintain how users currently connect to shared resources.
 
For PC/Windows users, this will not introduce any changes to the way you connect to your Zeus shares.  However, Mac users that do not currently connect to Zeus via the SMB connection (i.e CIFS) will need to be remapped on the morning of 6/13/18 in order to access the shares.  Our service desk will be ready to help with this change and you should contact us immediately for assistance.
 
What Do I Need To Do?
In order to prepare for the final migration of data to the new device we ask that users close out of all shared museum file directories and personal work drives on the night of June 12th before 6pm so that IT can work with Dell EMC and maximize our final migration window.  If files and folders are not closed out, IT will close them to ensure that the data is properly migrated to the new device.  To avoid losing changes to files please close out of all files and folders promptly before 6pm.

Please note that staff should not store non-work related items (music, personal photos, videos, etc.) on Zeus shared museum file directories and home directories, in keeping with the Museum�s Technology Resource Policy. This will help us keep up with the demand for storage needs and retain a longer backup retention policy for museum related work needs.  In the future, if you need additional storage capacity for your home directory, you can call the service desk or submit a request online.
 
As always, if you have any questions or issues, please contact our service desk, System Support Services, at ithelp@mos.org or call x0130.
 
Thank you,

Pat

This Saturday 5/26 at 11:30, we will have author Richard Munson at the CS&T Stage promoting his new book 'Tesla: Inventor of the Modern'. Come by and hear all about Nikola Telsa's life and accomplishments!

"Tesla�s inventions transformed our world, and his visions have continued to inspire great minds for generations.

Nikola Tesla invented the radio, robots, and remote control. His electric induction motors run our appliances and factories, yet he has been largely overlooked by history. In Tesla, Richard Munson presents a comprehensive portrait of this farsighted and underappreciated mastermind.

When his first breakthrough�alternating current, the basis of the electric grid�pitted him against Thomas Edison�s direct-current empire, Tesla�s superior technology prevailed. Unfortunately, he had little business sense and could not capitalize on this success. His most advanced ideas went unrecognized for decades: forty years in the case of the radio patent, longer still for his ideas on laser beam technology. Although penniless during his later years, he never stopped imagining. In the early 1900s, he designed plans for cell phones, the Internet, death-ray weapons, and interstellar communications. His ideas have lived on to shape the modern economy.

Who was this genius? Drawing on letters, technical notebooks, and other primary sources, Munson pieces together the magnificently bizarre personal life and mental habits of the enigmatic inventor. Born during a lightning storm at midnight, Tesla died alone in a New York City hotel. He was an acute germaphobe who never shook hands and required nine napkins when he sat down to dinner. Strikingly handsome and impeccably dressed, he spoke eight languages and could recite entire books from memory. Yet Tesla�s most famous inventions were not the product of fastidiousness or linear thought but of a mind fueled by both the humanities and sciences: he conceived the induction motor while walking through a park and reciting Goethe�s Faust.

Tesla worked tirelessly to offer electric power to the world, to introduce automatons that would reduce life�s drudgery, and to develop machines that might one day abolish war. His story is a reminder that technology can transcend the marketplace and that profit is not the only motivation for invention. This clear, authoritative, and highly readable biography takes account of all phases of Tesla�s remarkable life.

What's In Your Fish? Forum Tuesday 5/22

Hi all,

We're hosting a Forum event this Tuesday that might be of interest to many of you.  The program is called "What's In Your Fish?" and deals with the tradeoffs of neurotoxins in seafood, in the context of the well-known benefits of seafood consumption for brain development in young children and expecting/recent mothers.  We are co-presenting this event with the Boston University Superfund Research Program (BUSRP), for whom we are a subaward on their federal NIEHS grant.  We developed the forum materials in collaboration with BUSRP partners and a board of advisors from the local EPA office, Massachusetts state regulators, and other kinds of community and scientific experts.
 
The 90-minute Forum event will feature two consecutive case studies, each lasting about 40 minutes.  It�s taking place connected to a conference of Superfund Research Program grantees that will be happening that afternoon here at MOS. First, Kate Crawford from BU will talk about how researchers can assess and communicate risk about toxics in fish and then participants will consider and discuss a local case study about Chelsea Creek, which is part of the Mystic River and has experienced a history of environmental health challenges.  

Then, Celia Chen, Professor of Environmental Health at Dartmouth College in NH, will present her research about toxics in fish to the public that can impact the particularly vulnerable populations of with young children and pregnant women/prospective moms.  Participants will then discuss and design a risk advisory for how they would want to be advised of these risks as consumers and community members. 
 
Here's the link to sign up - the program is free but pre-registration is strongly encouraged.  https://www.mos.org/public-events/whats-in-your-fish.  Please help us spread the word!

Thanks and please feel free to contact me with any questions.

David

MOScar of the Month!

 

From the dozens of nominations we receive each week, the MOScars Team chooses a MOScar that we believe best exemplifies the spirit of the program across all categories each month.

 We had a 3 way tie this month!

 Our April MOScars of the Month are….

 

CONGRATULATIONS Ellie Starr!

Best Service to Guests

Recognized by Kaylan Petrie on 04/22/2018

 “The impact of a field trip to the Museum of Science is difficult to put into words, as it changes students, chaperones, and teachers in a multitude of ways intellectually and emotionally. For many schools, even those which are geographically close to us, the opportunity to come to our Museum is out of reach because of budgetary constraints related to admission and transportation.

Thanks to the hard work of Ellie during Stars of STEM, she was able to raise enough funds to eliminate this barrier for more than 2,000 students! A big THANK YOU from all of us in Education and Enrichment Programs!!”

 

CONGRATULATIONS Jeannine Madrid, Sue Stoessel, Mark Sherwood!

Best Service to Colleagues

Recognized by Megan Litwhiler & Karine Thate on 04/03/2018

 “When The Amazing Nano Brothers Jugglers Show had to cancel both of its Saturday performances at the last minute due to a medical emergency, our wonderful colleagues Jeannine, Sue, and Mark were there to help us make all the necessary arrangements. Jeannine walked us through what to do and who to contact. Mark helped us make sure that visitors would be aware of the schedule change. And Sue took care of all the day-of arrangements, such as signs and helping us alert staff to make sure that visitors would be aware that the shows had been canceled. Thanks so much to Jeannine, Mark, and Sue!”

 

CONGRATULATIONS Jeff Mills!

Best Service to Colleagues

Recognized by Yesenia Lopez on 04/18/2018

 “Jeff noticed that a black car in the Parking garage, who he suspected it was mine but was not sure, had a flat tire and he went ahead and filled it up. Later, he stop by the office and confirms that in fact the the car was mine and tried to guide me on next steps to fix the tire since this a recurrent issue.

I want to recognize Jeff not only because he helped me with the tire situation but he didn't do it because it was me, he did it because he is thoughtful like that. Jeff is one of a kind! :D”

Help Needed: Duck 'n' Hover Engineering Event

We are gearing up for our annual full day engineering event "Duck 'n' Hover" this Saturday, May 12th. 240 students will compete in randomly matched teams to design, build and test a wind-powered device that can lift the most rubber ducks in the Blue Wing. We are excited to offer this event for free to teens with free transportation for schools, and will be welcoming buses of students from Lawrence, Malden, Mattapan and the Metro West areas. The event is at capacity and we are excited to fill all of the spots for teens!


The weather is forecasting rain for this Saturday, and we expect a busy day at the Museum. We would very much like to have more volunteers to help with the event as wayfinders, helping at test stations, helping present engineering activities for families, and helping our "Meet an Engineer" stations of guests from Formlabs, the Wyss Institute, Tufts, and more. 


Please, if you are available to help, sign up for a GSE on quark. Full day and half day shifts are available and we will feed you. 


Thanks for checking your schedules, and thanks to those who have already signed up. This event is a lot of fun, and we couldn't do it without your help. 

The Duck 'n' Hover Team

I n order to control pests we need Your Help.

 We ask if you can please always report pest sightings as well as any evidence of pest activity in a timely manner.(Cockroaches, mice,mice droppings, ants, fruit flies, etc.)

The Facilities department offers the following options for reporting. Choose which ever is best for you.

1. Call Facilities at ext 0150
2. Submit a W.O. with Museum's On line work order (on Quark under Get It Done) or
3. Write the information as detailed as possible in the sighting book located at the Front desk.


More helpful tips that relate to pest prevention:


 � When reporting, be specific (date, type of pest seen, where, route of travel, your name & ext in case we need more information)

� Keep your space clean of clutter, food etc. Treats kept in office should be in covered containers.

� Do not change, remove or throw out equipment. Proper pest entrapment follow up will be done if someone in Facilities is notified.

� Keep the food disposal related items in a centralized location (we suggest the Kitchenettes areas rather than individual trash barrels)

� Abstain from eating in hallways, stairs, elevators or exhibit halls.

� Keep floor & walls clutter free (suggested clearance of 6 inches off floor and away from walls when possible)


Need some help cleaning? � Submit a work order for assistance to C&W

Need assistance with other items that could help improve your space? � Submit a work order to the Facilities Department.


If you have any questions, suggestions or concerns let me know.


Yesenia Lopez
Facilities Department

617-589-0150/0158
Spam email claiming to be Microsoft

There has been an increase in spam getting through to your email accounts.  The spam filter does catch the majority but it will not catch some of the more clever spam initially.  

Currently, one of the biggest phishing email coming through is claiming to be from Microsoft or Microsoft 365.  Please always verify that the email address came from the Microsoft domain.  Also, if you hover over a link in the email, that should also show that it is directed to Microsoft.
 
If it does not come from the Microsoft domain, please hit block sender.  It helps the spam filter better detect future spam email. 

Please also note that Microsoft will not send you an email asking you to change your museum account password.  Only someone in IT at the museum would ever contact you about your museum account/ password and we would call you.  

Please let me know if you have any questions or concerns.
Allie Curtis

Spring has sprung! And with it, all of the speed-walkers, joggers, rollerbladers, segway-enthusiasts, and selfie-takers are now officially out and about. It's a wonderful time to be on the Esplanade!

You're invited to... Researcher Small Talks!

Hi everyone,

Over the next two weeks, the Early Childhood Ed and Tech Studio teams will be hosting Discovery Center Living Laboratory Researchers onsite to chat with our educators about how they use the scientific process to answer their research questions in the fields of Psychology, Education, and Child Development.

Please join us to learn more about current research of local university partners happening in our very own halls, and/or to learn more about the Living Laboratory program (now at over 35 different sites, it started right here!).

Following is a schedule of who will be coming when, each researcher will be with us for � hour.  Feel free to join for any /all that you would like, invite other interested MOS colleagues, and email me if you would like any more information!

Friday May 4th at 9:30 in the Discovery Center (use side staff door in between the stairs and d�Arb Elevator)
Jim Gray- Research Scientist and Learning Lead, MIT Media Lab
The Social Machines group (of Media Lab) has several different projects going on within the Discovery Center, currently focusing on how to develop technology that assists in children�s language learning. This group is play-testing apps and responsive technologies that provide embedded feedback to children and/or caregivers.

Sunday May 6th at 9:30 in the Discovery Center (use side staff door in between the stairs and d�Arb Elevator)
Peter Blake- Principle Investigator, BU Social Development & Learning Lab
�Our research focuses on how children come to understand the social world.  We conduct cognitive and behavioral experiments with children from 2 to 12 years of age. We study things such as cooperation and competition, ownership and private property, fairness and other social norms, and learning through imitation and communication.�

Sunday May 6th at 12:30 in Hornblower
Rebecca Lange- Doctoral Student, Tufts U�s Cognitive Development Lab
Rebecca �is interested in basic cognitive and epistemological questions surrounding essentialist reasoning, causal explanation, language and thought, folk scientific and social theories, and conceptual change.�

Tuesday May 8th at 12:30 in the Engineers� Enclave
Leo Rosenstein- Lab Manager, MIT Language Acquisition Lab
�Typically, children acquire their language or languages within the first 5-6 years of life. How they accomplish this remarkable feat in such a short amount of time is the central topic of the study of child language acquisition.�

Wednesday May 9th at 9:30 in the Discovery Center (use side staff door in between the stairs and d�Arb Elevator)
Maire Diemer- Lan Manager, Northeastern U�s Communication Development Lab
�CDL researches how early experiences affects attentional processing and language development.  They study how children use audio-visual clues to enhance their attention to faces.�

Wednesday May 9th at 12:30 in Hornblower
Nat Rabb- Lab Manager, BC Arts & Mind Lab
Arts and Mind�s �research focuses on two areas of research on cognition in the arts. (1) The study of the creative process in the visual arts, including� how students make sense of the arts, and the role of arts in their lives...; (2) The study of the effects of music training on children's brain growth (through brain imaging) and on their cognition (musical, spatial, and verbal) and motoric development.

Thursday May 10th at 12:30 in Hornblower
Leo Rosenstein- Lab Manager, MIT Language Acquisition Lab
�Typically, children acquire their language or languages within the first 5-6 years of life. How they accomplish this remarkable feat in such a short amount of time is the central topic of the study of child language acquisition.�

Saturday May 12th, location TBA
Jess Beale- Doctoral Researcher, BU Developing Minds Lab
Infants �have to take the vast amount of visual information available in the world and carve it up into the meaningful units that are most relevant to us as humans: namely, inanimate objects and animate agents.  In the Developing Minds Lab, we are interested in how infants and children perceive, understand, and remember objects and agents.�

Tuesday May 15th at 9:30 in the Discovery Center (use side staff door in between the stairs and d�Arb Elevator)
Emily Palmer- Lab Manager, BU Social Learning Lab
Children are little scientists, but it is not possible to learn everything one must know through direct experimentation alone.  For many topics, children must rely on the testimony of others to learn how the world works.   How do children make decisions about who is a good source of information, and who to trust when learning about different topics?

Cheers,
Katie

Duck 'n' Hover, our annual full-day engineering event, is next Saturday, May 12th! Please help us get the word out to friends about our engineering challenge for high school students. Randomly matched teams will be competing to design, build and test a wind-powered device that can hover at a target height in the Blue Wing carrying the largest payload of rubber ducks.  

For museum guests, the day includes several engineering and design activities occurring throughout the building in partnership with the Discovery Center and Tech Studio. Additionally, there will be "Meet an Engineer" stations with guests from the Boston tech community, and a rubber duck themed finale featuring ducks on parachutes, over 1000 rubber ducks, and a 6-foot "Mother Duck". There will be prizes and give-aways for guests as well.  

We are currently looking for VOLUNTEERS to help us support this great day of engineering and duct tape. 

GSE's have been POSTED: 
Full or half day GSE credit is available as well as an awesome free t-shirt and pizza lunch. Possible jobs include being part of the set up team, monitoring a testing station or materials store, greeting guests in the lobby, facilitating a design activity for museum guests, etc.  

If you would like to sign up to help please go to the following link:  
tinyurl.com/ducknhover2018volunteer

We are also looking for TEEN PARTICIPANTS. If you know any students that would be interested in this engaging, hands-on, and super fun engineering challenge, please encourage them to sign up at the following link: 
tinyurl.com/ducknhover2018 


If you have any questions regarding this event please email  
techstudio@mos.org  

Thanks everyone in advance for your help and support for this event. We hope to see you there!  

The Duck 'n' Hover Team

As FY18 is winding down and A Mirror Maze Numbers in Nature is getting deinstalled, here�s a quick summary of the traveling exhibits currently scheduled for FY19!
 
Crocs: Ancient Predators in a Modern World (Peeling Productions)
Stearns Hall
5/19/18 (Member Preview) � 9/3/18
"This exhibition examines the long and complex history of crocodilians, their influence in human cultures, and their precarious future in a world dominated by people. Cutting-edge science, live animals, and interactive components emphasize the importance of preserving these elegant predators. This traveling exhibition explores the complex lives of crocodilians. The exhibition includes a digital curator to introduce the main interpretive themes; 4 living dioramas complete with live crocodilians (Siamese crocodile, American alligator hatchlings, African dwarf crocodile, broad-snouted caimans), naturalistic decor, filtration, and life support systems; 5 modeled dioramas with life-sized museum quality replicas in habitats scenes; 15 interactive components; a mini theater; fossil artifacts; and more than 40 informational panels."
 
For images, visit:
http://peelingproductions.com/traveling-exhibitions/crocs-ancient-predators-in-a-modern-world/ 
 
 
Space: An Out-of-Gravity Experience (Science Museum of Minnesota; SMEC exhibit)
Nichols Gallery
6/23/18 (Member Preview) � 1/1/19
"This hands-on, climb-aboard cosmic adventure of science fun and learning invites explorers of all ages to understand the rewards and challenges of working in such a harsh environment�from operating a robotic arm to managing a limited power supply to discovering why working in a space glove is so difficult.
Experience the sights, sounds, and smells on board the International Space station, and try your hand at some of the feats of engineering that support astronauts as they navigate the unforgiving vacuum of space. Through games, multimedia components, and interactives, learn how they eat, sleep, and even use the restroom. Witness firsthand the innovations that make life in space possible�and discover the triumphs that await in orbit and beyond"!
 
For images and a video of the exhibit, visit:
http://www.spaceexhibit.org 
 
 
*NEW*
Nature�s Superheroes: Life at the Limits (American Museum of Natural History)
Nichols Gallery
2/14/19 � 5/5/19
"Discover bizarre mating serenades, explore a mysterious cave environment where animals live without eyes, and investigate how a giant elephant seal can hold its breath for nearly two hours while diving a mile to find food. Life at the Limits offers a fascinating lens on the breathtaking diversity of the natural world and the incredible power of evolution to shape exceptional responses to the challenges, and opportunities, of life on Earth. Multi-sensory experiences, immersive scenic displays, and hands-on interactives bring exceptional creatures to life." 
Themes include: Start (reproduction and mating), Breath, Move, Sense & Eat, Endure, Finish (long and short lifespans).

For images and a video of the exhibit, visit:
https://www.amnh.org/global-business-development/traveling-exhibitions/nature-s-superheroes-life-at-the-limits 


If you have any questions, feel free to call or email me (x4456; gignarri@mos.org)

Greetings,

A number of fundamental changes are afoot for the Museum�s Grants Planning Committee (GPC).��If you are responsible for developing gift/grant proposals on the Museum�s behalf, here�s what you need to know.��(If you�re not responsible for proposals, spare yourself the rest of this posting.)

Composition and Process

First and foremost, the Committee itself has been rejiggered to be leaner and meaner.��GPC is now just Andrew Russell, representing Advancement, and Christa Gonsalves, representing Finance.��Other folks from across the Museum still have roles in the process, but Andrew and Christa are the point people for GPC Review.

The purpose of the GPC process has been clarified to emphasize GPC�s role as proposal coordination: making sure that everyone involved in a proposed project is looped in, that proposals follow MOS and funder rules, and that the proposal is properly assembled, on time and with all its i�s dotted and t�s crossed.��The vetting and approving role GPC had during the last Campaign has been deprecated (although �approval� language does still appear on some of the GPC forms due to how the Museum�s Hub works).

Currently, GPC still meets monthly to perform �Step One� review, and this schedule should inform your proposal gameplanning.��However, GPC is exploring having more frequent meetings to be able to more nimbly respond to employee submissions.

Forms

The old, tutti-frutti colored forms on Quark which still thought in terms of a Campaign Priority List that is almost a decade stale are DEAD.

GPC forms now live on the Hub (hub.mos.org).��The Grants Planning Committee is one of the �Communities� on the Hub.��On the GPC Hub page you�ll find links to the Step One and Step Two forms, as well as a number of useful documents � reference materials, sample proposals, and, most importantly, a guide to the new GPC forms themselves (�GPC Forms Reference�).��Read it.��Learn it.��Love it.

The newly-fledged GPC Hub forms are still testing their wings.��(That�s a poetic way of saying you�re all beta-testers.)��If the forms do not behave as expected, please contact Stan.��For more basic questions about the GPC process and forms, please contact Andrew or Christa (after checking the wonderful reference materials on the Hub page).

Stan

Vehicle Use

It is the policy of the Museum that cell phones and pagers are not to be used by staff while operating a motor vehicle.� Using telecommunications devices, even with a hands -free accessory, is a distraction that reduces the driver�s ability to react to hazards.� This applies to personal cell phones used for, or while conducting, Museum business.

If you need to make or receive a call while driving, please carefully pull over or park somewhere (but only when it is safe and easy to do so), stop the vehicle, and put it in park before using your phone.

NEW SIGN UP PROCESS-Clean Up Boat GSE's

Charles River Clean Up Boat GSE�s-New GSE Sign-Up Instructions for This Year!

**Please read all the way through**

Clean Up Boat Season is here!

Since 2007 the Museum has partnered with the Charles River Clean Up Boat, a registered 501(c)(3) organization, who�s primary focus is to keep the Charles River clean of floating trash and debris. This organization has done a great job keeping our river beautiful and has received many accolades for its work. 

In late 2017, the Founder of the Charles River Clean Up Boat, Tom McNichol, passed away after a long battle with cancer. In order to keep the Charles River Clean Up Boat organization going, Boston Duck Tours and the Museum of Science have joined forces to oversee the activities and will help ensure the health of this organization for years to come!

NEW GSE SIGN-UP PROCESS THIS YEAR

How do I sign up?

**You must complete the following steps in the order listed**

1. Go to the website- cleanupboat.org.>Click on �Volunteers�>within the first paragraph, click on the word �here� >this will bring you to the volunteer sign up page. 

2. Sign up for an available date, either under the Volunteer 1 or Volunteer 2 fields (please know that the maximum number of Volunteers is now two per day) and then fill in your contact information and select from the drop down, that you are a Museum of Science Employee.

3. You will receive a confirmation email from �Signup Genius� (Be sure to check your clutter/junk folders if you don�t see it right away)

4. Next, sign up for the corresponding GSE through our GSE sign up system.  Please note that the GSE dates listed on the Museum�s GSE sign-up page may not match as being available on cleanupboat.org. This is due to other volunteers, separate from MOS employees, signing up through the cleanupboat.org website. This is why you must sign up on the cleanupboat.org website first.
If you signed for a shift on cleanupboat.org and notice that there is no corresponding Museum GSE sign up available, please let me know.

What if I need to cancel or reschedule my GSE?

1. Cancel your GSE using the Museum via the GSE cancellation process.

2. Go to cleanupboat.org and back to the Volunteer sign up page. Right above where the list of dates begins, you will see a link titled �Already signed up? You can change your sign up.� and follow the instructions from there (I have found that the easiest thing to do is the enter email option and it will email you a link to cancel) Once you have cancelled your day, you will receive a cancellation confirmation email. 

If you are cancelling your GSE within 3 days of your scheduled date, in addition to canceling on the volunteer page, please contact your Captain directly to let them know.  Captain contact information is located at the top of the volunteer sign-up page.

Read over the GSE description carefully and be sure to sign up for a day that you know you can commit to. 

This GSE is fun, rewarding, and on most days, a good way to get out and enjoy the weather!

Dear Colleagues,

It is the policy of the Museum of Science that all employees should be able to enjoy a work environment free of sexual harassment. This requires that each employee treat every other employee, and other individuals with whom the employee has contact, with courtesy and respect in the course of the employee’s employment.

We believe that this policy is critical to creating and maintaining a culture of inclusion and safety in the work environment. We are asking that all staff take our e-learning module entitled “Museum of Science- Anti-Discrimination & Harassment” by May 4, 2018.

Instructions on how to access this e-learning are attached

If you were hired after 1/1/2018 you are not required to re-take this training

If any employee believes that they have been the subjected to any form of sexual harassment or that they have witnessed this behavior in the workplace, this concern should be brought to the person’s supervisor, any member of management or Human Resources so that it is appropriately addressed.

If you have any questions regarding these policies, please contact any of the following people in Human Resources:

Britton O’Brien x0124

Christine Flebbe x0178

Margo Smith x0123

If you need any help with this e-learning, please contact Lorah Broderick

 

Museum of Science - Anti-Discrimination & Harassment E-Learning Instructions

1. Visit https://collabornation.net/login/mos.

2. Log into your account with your CollaborNation credentials (remember: this is not tied to your MOS log in).

  • If you have forgotten your username or password you can select the “Forgot Password or Email?” link to retrieve your login.
  • If you do not have an account please create one.

3. Once you are logged in you will be brought to a page called “My Courses”.

4. Look for “Museum of Science - Anti-Discrimination & Harassment” on your Course Dashboard > select “Take Course”.

  • If you do not see this on your dashboard, please search for it in the Course Catalog.

5. Follow the prompts of the training until the end, once completed you will receive a certificate of completion. You do not need to send the certificate to HR, we will have record of your completion.


Please have this course completed by May 4, 2018

The sky is falling!

China's derelict space station, Tiangong-1, will be crashing back to Earth sometime Saturday or Sunday. The landing zone is anywhere between 43 degrees north latitude and 43 degrees south latitude.

Satellites of this size don't entirely vaporize when they re-enter the atmosphere, and pieces may survive to impact the Earth's surface. Skylab, a US space station from the 1970s, crashed back to Earth in Australia in 1979 (NASA was fined $400 by the Australian government for littering.)

While the chances of your being hit by debris are vanishingly small, the satellite should put on quite a fireworks show as it breaks up, so when you're out & about this weekend, keep an eye on the skies!

You can follow along with the predictions for Tiangong-1's demise here: http://blogs.esa.int/rocketscience/2018/03/26/tiangong-1-reentry-updates/

Day 2

Take some time to relax with the stress-reducing trend – coloring!  Many have found coloring to be calming, and say that it is similar to other repetitive tasks, such as knitting, that allow for our brains to focus on the moment and clear our minds. While you are focused on staying in the lines, and being creative with your colors negative thoughts are pushed out of your mind. This simple activity can reduce your stress and anxiety in the moment and help you learn to slow down over time.

If you’re interested in reading more about coloring and mindfulness, check out this article, “What’s the Deal with Adult Coloring Books?”

CONGRATULATIONS Kim Cooper-Vernon!

Best Service to Guests

Recognized by Anonymous on 02/26/2018

“Kim and I were walking past the parking pay kiosks where I visitor was having problems paying during vacation week. It would not take their card. I went to get someone to help and Kim stayed with the visitor. While I was finding someone Kim try her card and it worked. Kim ended up paying for the visitors parking. Without a pause Kim told the visitor not to worries about it and to have a great day and walked away. What I great service to our guest. Kim turn a negative situation into a positive one. Way to go Kim!”

 

CONGRATULATIONS Adinah Greene!

Best Service to Colleagues

Recognized by Kim Cooper-Vernon on 02/21/2018

 

“I was driving down 1, early one day,

When my car hit a pothole, to my dismay.

I swerved and maneuvered to the side of the road,

and lo--there was my tire, flat as a smashed toad.

 

I called up my manager (it was 6 am)

and told him, distraught, how my tire had gone blam.

"My depart's at 7:20, I have animals to get--

but I'm stuck out in Saugus, what should I do next?"

 

It was then I remembered, like a wave on the beach,

there was only one person who wasn't scheduled to teach.

She even knew the program I was due to take out--

"It's perfect! I'll just call her and we'll figure it out!"

 

And so my Adaptations were taught by Adinah Greene,

who's a real fine lady--I'm sure you know what I mean.

I can't thank her enough, when all is said and done,

though you can bet I'll be more careful when I'm driving on 1!”

 

Getting a MOScar is great feeling, giving a MOScar is an even better one. It only takes a minute but can make someone’s entire day. Remember - no deed is too small!

The bomb cyclones just keep on coming - our third storm in less than two weeks produced the highest snow total in the month of March for the city of Boston (14.5", beating the previous record of 13.2" from 1956). Some areas of the state got over two feet of snow, and meteorologists are already watching a developing weather pattern that could affect us sometime next week (but that won't pan out...right?!)

While shoveling snow can be good exercise (ALL the Active For Life points!), it can also be dangerous if you don�t plan ahead. One rule of thumb for safe shoveling is to do it early and often � although it can be annoying to constantly shovel, guidelines recommend staying ahead of the storm so that you�re not faced with one insurmountable task of heavy, wet snow to clear, but instead take the time to shovel several times when it will be lighter and more manageable. Check out some other tips for shoveling snow safely, brought to you by the Snow & Ice Management Association (yep, apparently that�s a thing).

Stay safe and enjoy the late winter weather!

This Thursday, March 15, Facilities and Public Safety will begin removing the current bike cage in order to install a new one. Along with an expanded footprint, the new design will feature �hoop� style racks for 32 bikes, lighting, security camera visibility for Public Safety, and badge access. This work will take several weeks and the new bike cage is expected to open Monday, April 2.

Prior to decommissioning the existing structure, it is important that all bikes are removed from the cage before the morning of Thursday, March 15. Any bikes left behind will be disposed of by Public Safety. We will be placing two racks temporarily in the area just outside of the current bike cage in the basement level of the garage, in existing motorcycle and EV parking spaces. Given the limited space, we kindly request that you email Mike Sullivan (msullivan@mos.org) if you plan on commuting by bike during this time. This will ensure we plan for enough bike parking during the transition. Please also bring a lock as this temporary setup will not be cage secured. Lastly, please be prepared to park/lock your bicycles in one of the public racks near the lobby/rock garden if these temporary racks are full. We appreciate your patience while we work to greatly improve our bike cage facility.

In order to be able to use the new bike cage with your MOS badge when it is open, you must register information with Public Safety. Although Public Safety and IIT are working to develop a Hub page form to automate this process (similar to the Garage Access form), it is unlikely this will be ready before the new cage is. In the meantime, please e-mail msullivan@mos.org with the following information before April 2 for badge access to the cage:
- Your name
- Your bike make, model, and color
- A contact phone number

Please understand this information is only being collected to monitor the safety and security of Museum riders and their bicycles. This will not be public information and will only be used in the event Public Safety needs to reach you. Once the Hub page is active, existing rider information submitted by email will be transferred to the database so you will not need to resubmit anything.

We�re very excited for the enhancements that are being made to our bike cage facility, but apologize for any temporary inconvenience caused by the installation and thank you in advance for your cooperation. Please contact Mike Sullivan at x4495 with any questions/concerns.

Thank you to everyone for your help, support, and participation in National Engineers Week this year! Between February 18th and 24th, we are proud to say that we engaged 10,944 visitors in our engineering programming, activities, and presentations throughout the museum. Through the generous support of NCEES, the museum was also able to bring 100 members of the Boys and Girls Club to visit the Museum and view Dream Big at no cost, as well as host an additional seven free screenings of the film during the week which 842 visitors attended. This brings our total visitor engagement number up to 11,886 for the week!  

Special thanks to Discovery Center, CS&T, and EHI staff who helped make this possible with their additional engineering programming throughout the week, as well as to Engineering is Elementary staff who ran their engineering activities for hundreds of museum visitors in the Engineering Design Workshop on Tuesday and Wednesday afternoons. In addition, thank you to Volunteer Services and Corporate Relations/Advancement for helping recruit and train our corporate volunteers. Thank you everyone!

UPDATE 3: Pesky winds have pushed the launch back again, to 3:45.
UPDATE 2: Launch pushed back again to 3:05!
UPDATE 1: Launch is now set for 2:20pm - we'll still be watching on stage!

Today (Tues. 2/6), SpaceX will launch their Falcon Heavy rocket on its inaugural flight. With three booster cores strapped side-by-side and 27 rocket engines, this test flight will send SpaceX founder Elon Musk's Midnight Cherry Tesla Roadster into a solar orbit that takes it near Mars. All three boosters will attempt landings back on the Earth.

If successful, the Falcon Heavy will become the most powerful operational rocket in the world by a factor of 2. Musk has said that there is a 50-70% chance of everything going right, and as long as the rocket clears the launch pad before it blows up he'd consider it a success.

Join us at the CS&T Stage to watch history live! The launch window opens today at 1:30pm (now 3:45).

On Wednesday, the Moon will be doing a whole lot of interesting things at the same time. Unfortunately, just about none of them will be visible to us in Boston.

Firstly, the Moon will be full on Wednesday. The moon's distance from us changes very slightly, and this full moon happens to coincide with it being about as close as it gets - what we call a Supermoon. So this full moon will look very slightly larger than usual - but probably nothing you'd notice ordinarily.

This full moon also qualifies as a Blue Moon. This can be either the second full moon in a calendar month, or the fourth full moon in a season. Since we had a full moon on Jan. 1st, this will be the twice-a-month variety. This isn't a particularly rare occurrence, and since it's really just a quirk of our calendar, the moon won't appear any different.

Finally, there will be a lunar eclipse Wednesday. This is when the moon passes through the Earth's shadow. As it does so, light filtering through the Earth's atmosphere falls on it - but only red light, giving it the name Blood Moon. Unfortunately, this is happening just as the moon sets for us here in Boston very early Wednesday morning. By the time it comes back up at sunset, the eclipse will be long over.

So there you have it! The Super Blue Blood Moon is getting a lot of air time in the media but it won't be particularly exciting. For a great show, stay tuned for next week's launch of the most powerful rocket in forty years!

You may have noticed in the news that many people are coming down with the Flu.

Flu symptoms may include: Fever, chills, muscle aches, cough, congestion, runny nose, headaches, and fatigue.

If you feel sick, consider your coworkers and use your sick time to help prevent the spread of germs. Massachusetts employers are required to offer all employees sick time. Part-time and non-benefit eligible staff accrue 1 hour of sick time for every 30 hours worked. Full-time benefits eligible staff receive 5 sick days in their first year and 10 sick days each year thereafter. You may also use your vacation time if necessary.

Ways to prevent getting the flu:

  • Get a flu shot - it�s the best way to protect from the flu.
  • Boost your immunity with sleep, good nutrition and hydration.
  • Wash your hands and don�t touch your face. Carry hand sanitizer, too.
  • Cover your cough. Cough or sneeze into tissues to contain germs.
  • Wipe down and disinfect frequently touched surfaces to kill germs.

    • If you haven�t had a flu shot, you should still try and get one! Many doctor offices still offer flu shot clinics, as well as pharmacies and grocery stores. We suggest calling in advance to make sure vaccinations are still available. Here are some local pharmacies/retailers that are offering flu shots:

    CVS

    Walgreens

    RiteAid

    Stop & Shop

    The copay amount for the vaccination is dependent on your health insurance coverage. If you�re a Harvard Pilgrim member, there is no copay at these stores. As long as the pharmacy is contracted with Harvard Pilgrim, the immunization is covered in full. All you need to do is ask at the pharmacy if they accept HPHC, which most of them do. Also, if you�re a Harvard Pilgrim member, don�t forget about their Telemedicine feature Doctor On Demand. If you or someone in your family is sick, you can Skype with a medical professional without leaving your house (normal copay applies).

    Don't "wait and see" � get help right away. Early flu treatment (within 72 hours of exposure to the virus) has been proven to reduce the length and severity of illness. If you think you might have the flu, or have been exposed to someone with the flu, see a health care professional right away.

    Please protect yourself and your coworkers by taking the necessary precautions and please stay home if you have a fever and don�t feel well. Staff who have the flu should not return to work until they have been without a fever for 24 hours.

Great News: CRM System Services and Annie Petroff

As we anticipated when we adopted a modern customer relationship management/POS system, the volume of work related to Tessitura has evolved and continued to grow as the Museum�s use of Tessitura has matured. Cross divisionally we have a high volume of front end configuration, coordination, pilot testing, training, and strategizing as we seek to leverage the capabilities of our new CRM/POS system. To that end we are creating the CRM System Services Department to work with business side users in collaboration with IIT staff who provide technical support. 

Annie Petroff, who quickly made herself an indispensable resource for Tessitura users across the Museum since her arrival at the Museum just a little over a year ago, is being promoted to Manager of the CRM System Services Department. Please join me in congratulating Annie!  

In addition, we are seeking a CRM System Services Coordinator to round out the department. We welcome qualified applicants and referrals. The position is currently posted internally.

Thank you!
Come say farewell to Caroline Lowenthal

Hi all,

Just a reminder that we are saying farewell to Caroline today in Hornblower starting at 2 PM.

After 5 years and many great Forum projects, Caroline Lowenthal is departing the Museum for an exciting new opportunity working as an analyst with the US Department of Transportation. Her last day at the Museum will be on January 17th. Caroline served as Coordinator of the Forum department, working on efforts such as the Provocative Questions exhibit, two World Wide Views deliberations to inform the United Nations, the Building with Biology project, a forum on self-driving cars, and much, much more.

Please join us on her last day, Wednesday, January 17 from 2-3:30 PM in Hornblower to say a fond farewell.  We'll showcase some of Caroline's great work over the years and share stories.  We'll coordinate a potluck; if you'd like to bring something please email David at dsittenfeld@mos.org.

New Prototype in Behind the Scenes

I am happy to introduce a new prototype in Behind the Scenes.  We are now hosting a prototype component titled "Design Build, Test" which has been created by the NISE Network* collaborative as a part of its upcoming NASA-funded mini-exhibition "Sun, Earth, Universe". This component is a hands-on engineering challenge, in which visitors design, build, and test a model satellite. 

While the component is in its nearly-final form, we are hosting a copy here at MOS in order to make some final observations about wear and tear, which we will share with the NISE Network. The prototype will be in the space through mid- March. Please stop by and check it out!

* The NISE Network is is a community of informal educators and scientists dedicated to supporting learning about science, technology, engineering, and math (STEM) across the United States. The Network is co-led by Arizona State University, Science Museum of Minnesota and the Museum of Science Boston   This collaborative is affiliated with a variety of projects including the Nanoscale Informal Science Education Network, which is responsible for the Nano mini exhibit and Nano Days, and Building with Biology initiative. To learn more, check out http://www.nisenet.org/about
